problem.tex: State the following, clearly and completely: (a) The definition we have been using for a function $f:U\to\mathbb{C}$ to be analytic on $U$, where $U$ is an open subset of $\mathbb{C}$. (b) Let $\gamma:[a,b]\to\mathbb{C}$ be continuously differentiable, $a,b\in\mathbb{R}, a< b$. Let $f:U\to\mathbb{C}$, an open subset of $\mathbb{C}$ containing $\gamma$. State the definition of \[\int_\gamma f(z)dz.\]

solution.tex: a) (assuming this is a class which follows Conway) The function $f:U\to\mathbb{C}$ is analytic at a point $a\in U$ if $f$ is $C^1$ as a real-valued function and if \[\lim_{h\to0}\frac{f(a+h)-f(a)}{h}\] exists, recalling that this limit is defined with neighborhoods in $\mathbb{C}$. We call $f$ analytic in $U$ if it is analytic at every point in $U$. b) This integral, the path integral, is defined as a limit of Riemann sums. Let $a=x_0< x_1<\cdots< x_n=b$ be a partition of $[a,b]$. The corresponding Riemann sum is \[\sum_{k=1}^nf(x_k)(x_k-x_{k-1}).\] The path integral is defined as the limit of these Riemann sums, taken as the mesh of the partitions goes to 0.
